awd_titl_txt: Modulating the Adhesion, Friction and Lubrication Characteristics of Few-Atom Thick Materials in Aqueous Environment over Several Length Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-dimensional (2D) materials are drawing significant attention because their atomic size results in unique material properties. Although water is often present in these systems and it significantly affects the microelectromechanical system or device performance, very little is known about the interfacial properties of 2D materials in the presence of water. This is partially due to the challenges involved in contamination-free, controlled processing of high quality 2D materials, which limits fundamental studies and applications. This project will study the science associated with the interfacial properties of 2D materials. Since the technology has direct applicability to micro and nano-scale devices, the research has the potential to impact the automotive, consumer electronic, aerospace and defense sectors, and therefore directly impacts economic welfare and national security.  The research will contribute to the development of work force in the U.S. by training two graduate students research assistants. Further, the PIs? integrated education plan is designed to spark the early interest of K-12 students in STEM and inspire undergraduate and graduate students to further advance their interests in the intersection of 2D materials and surface science and engineering. In addition, the PIs will focus on broadening nano-engineering education by engaging student veterans and high school and minority students via summer research opportunities and field trips. The PIs will also actively pursue outreach activities, including interactive lectures and hands-on activities.

In order to fill the knowledge gap of interfacial properties of 2D materials in aqueous environment, two major lines of research will be followed: (1) establish manufacturing methods for single- and few-layer graphene and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) that afford control of their quality, the number of layers and substrate-induced doping characteristics over several length scales and (2) fundamentally comprehend, measure and model friction, adhesion, and lubrication by few-atomic thick materials in aqueous environment. The research hypothesis is that substrate-induced doping can be a means to modulate the interactions of few-atomic thick materials with water and ions, as well as their interfacial mobility, and therefore, it can be used to control electrical double layer, friction, adhesion and lubrication mechanisms. Preparation of contamination-free, single-crystalline graphene and MoS2 layers with controlled substrate-induced doping will enable careful study of interfacial properties of 2D materials in aqueous environment. Measurements with a surface forces apparatus (SFA) will provide thorough data of interfacial forces, which will be precisely modeled to quantify the effects of the substrate-induced doping. The ease of preparing samples for atomic force microscopy (AFM) will enable to also investigate substrate-induced doping via metal thin films, a higher number of ionic compositions and also to qualitatively compare the interfacial behavior of MoS2 and graphene with several other (exfoliated) 2D materials and with the bulk crystals. Ultimately, a theory for the relation between substrate-induced doping of 2D materials and their adhesive and frictional characteristics in the presence of water will be established.

por.por_cntn:
As the boundaries of technology move to smaller scales, understanding the fundamental mechanics of nanoscale systems and how to control them are key to advancing science. Small devices which rely on mechanical, electrical, and chemical interactions (referred to as nano- and microelectromechanical devices; N/MEMs) are much more affected by interfacial forces (i.e. forces between surfaces) than larger-scale technologies due to their inherently larger surface-to-volume ratio. Understood phenomena at the macroscale in areas like fluid dynamics change and are not as fully explained at the nanoscale, indicating a need for further understanding of the fundamental physicochemical interactions to design and optimize functional devices. Interactions between materials at these small scales are dependent on individual molecular-level interactions, meaning that, for example, even “small” amounts of water from ambient humidity can have impacts on performance. New types of nanomaterials with unique functionalities are key to advancing nanotechnologies; two-dimensional (2D) materials (thermodynamically stable materials with thickness of just one to a few atoms) are an important and exciting example. Graphene is a one atomic layer thick 2D material of carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice that exhibits a variety of exotic properties and serves as a model 2D material. Of relevance to this project are graphene’s low coefficient of friction and ability to be influenced by its immediate environment to adjust its surface interactions (referred to here as doping). Our research investigated how graphene covering different types of more traditional material surfaces and used in different liquid and gas environments responds to doping in the context of sliding interactions and near-surface forces, demonstrating that graphene’s unique properties and tunability make graphene and other 2D materials versatile candidates for incorporation in N/MEMs and other nanotechnologies.

            The methods of this project were primarily experimental, where different types of graphene devices were prepared and friction, adhesion, and other near-surface forces were characterized at the nanoscale using instruments that directly measure nanoscale forces, supplemented by additional forms of characterization. An important overall result from these studies is the ability to create the graphene sheets and reliably transfer them to a variety of different substrate types, chosen both to create intentionally doped graphene and relevance to applications. Especially unique to our project is the development of a technique that allows highly precise nanoscale measurements between two graphene surfaces, a normally difficult system to experimentally investigate. The technique requires careful preparation but allows measurements not possible using other methods, contributing to key fundamental understanding of nanoscale forces in 2D material systems. We expect this to enable further development of models and testing of theories to guide design of 2D material nanotechnologies.  

We investigated graphene surface forces in different liquid environments in addition to water, focusing on factors affecting a unique nanoscale phenomenon that results in liquids flowing faster than expected for similar conditions at large scales, especially near carbon material surfaces like graphene. We found that the ability of the liquid molecules to preferentially structure themselves in layers near the graphene surface has a large effect on the enhanced flow, but changes in graphene’s doping because of different substrates can affect the flow enhancement to a similar order of magnitude. The same substrate for graphene can also increase or decrease the flow enhancement depending on the properties of the liquid. This indicates that graphene nanotechnologies used in liquid environments can be intentionally optimized by changing graphene’s substrate to function in different types of liquids while keeping graphene’s unique benefits. We were also able to show through measuring friction with a nanoscale probe that the flow enhancement, measured previously at the scale of many liquid molecules using a micrometer sized sphere, is related to and predicted by the ease of movement of the individual liquid molecules. In addition to informing graphene device design, this also reveals some of the fundamental interactions contributing to the enhanced flow, allowing extension of our findings to new systems.

We also looked at graphene in gas environments, now with a focus on dynamic doping using an electric field to allow modulation of surface interactions after a graphene device has already been fabricated and is in use. Here we found that for certain types of materials sliding on graphene the usually low friction can be switched off and on by changing the strength of the electric field the graphene is exposed to, increasing the friction force in the off state to a magnitude similar to non-graphene surfaces. Careful force measurements at the scale of atoms revealed that this behavior is caused by creating different ways for energy to dissipate, a fundamental phenomenon which suggests a method for controlling friction in systems outside of graphene surfaces. Our development of a new technique and investigations of graphene in these contexts demonstrate that graphene and 2D materials are a versatile nanomaterial family that can contribute to more functional nanotechnologies.
